data.text: @RonBrownstein @ozy William McAdoo, 1924, nearly won the Dem nomination as a California Senator

@Scott_Calvert @ErnieBass3 @RonBrownstein @ozy I disagree --- it's about thinking where people's political constituencies are. Obama had been elected in Illinois and it's where his base was. No D has drawn on that from West.
@DanielPMalloy @ErnieBass3 @RonBrownstein @ozy I know it's dealt with in the article, but it seems more like ignoring a data point that doesn't fit the thesis.
@DanielPMalloy @ErnieBass3 @RonBrownstein @ozy Um, Obama is from HI. Unless you ask Trump, I mean.
@ErnieBass3 @RonBrownstein @ozy I mean the "modern" Western states as currently constituted: AK, HI, CA, OR, WA, AZ, NM, WY, CO, NV, ID, MT, UT

@RonBrownstein @ozy Also: Ronald Reagan (R–California) and Bill Clinton (D–Arkansas) were the last U.S. president from their parties who could carry their home states. Since 1992, the avg. number of carried states—29. It would pretty much take 40 carried states for a R to win CA and a D to win AR.

@RonBrownstein @ozy Ds could’ve nominated CA Gov. Jerry Brown in the Democratic pickup year 1992. Ds counter-realigned the map—after Republicans won over the south, in the 1980s—as CA, CT, DE, IL, ME (state), MD, NJ, and VT flipped D and have not carried R since. Alas, Brown was not a strong enough.
@RonBrownstein @kkondik @ozy Under-appreciated in this piece is the influence that Labor has had in D politics. As Labor influence wanes, I’d think the chances of a Western D nominee increase
@ErnieBass3 @RonBrownstein @ozy For his time, yes, but we were limiting our definition to the modern Western states.
@RonBrownstein @blakehounshell @ozy California stands ready to provide Dem candidates
@RonBrownstein @ozy Any attempt to look for trends in presidential elections falls apart because of the tiny sample size. Basically every president is an outlier.
